ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SKILLS PROGRAMME FOR UPGRADING AND RESILIENCE (SPUR)

(Update)

     1.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Manpower (a) what is the progress on the Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR); and (b) whether the Ministry has plans to increase the subsidy for SPUR.

     The Minister of State for Manpower (Mr Lee Yi Shyan) (for the Minister for Manpower): Sir, the response to SPUR has been very encouraging. As at end of February 2009, over 43,000 workers have been committed for SPUR training. These include about 700 companies who have committed 27,000 workers for training under SPUR. This is an increase from the total number of 20,500 workers just a month ago. Take, for example, Gain City, a well-established consumer electronics and home appliances company with a workforce of about 500 employees. Recently, Gain City sent 21 staff for a sales course at the Singapore Institute of Retail Studies (SIRS). They found the course very useful as it provided them with relevant tools and approaches for conducting sales and serving their customers. Furthermore, the company was able to claim for Absentee Payroll (AP) which helped to defray the costs during the period when the staff underwent training.

     Besides employer-sponsored trainees, about 17,000 individuals have enrolled directly for SPUR training at the Career Centres, CET Centres, ITE and the five local polytechnics. An example is Mdm Mualidayanti, aged 36. She was a production worker until she was retrenched last year. She was referred by the South West CDC for Certified Service Professional

Column: 3623

(CSP) training in February 2009, which gave her the skills and confidence needed to switch to a job in the service industry.  She has completed the training and found a job as a Retail Assistant at Popular Pte Ltd. I am pleased to note that she is adjusting well and enjoys her current job.

 

     To achieve the right outcomes for employers and trainees, we have been very selective in expanding the number of courses under SPUR. We select and design SPUR courses to ensure quality and relevance of training so that trainees employability are maximised.  SPUR courses, including those for PMETs, are also heavily subsidised at 90%.  The principle of co-funding is important as it ensures that individuals and employers are committed to the training and take ownership of outcomes.  However, to ease cashflow, course fee payment can be made on a per-module basis.  CET Centres also provide deferred payment arrangements.  Individuals who still face financial difficulties can approach our Career Centres at the Community Development Councils, or e2i, for assistance on a case-by-case basis.  They can also seek assistance from the Self Help Groups (SHGs) which may provide training loans and additional training subsidies for job seekers from low-income families.

     Er Lee Bee Wah (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I have one supplementary question.  How many of these programmes are suitable for PMETs and how many of these programmes are suitable for those who are retrenched from the construction industry? 

     Mr Lee Yi Shyan:   Sir, the SPUR programmes have been increased from 200 to 800 this year.  Out of the 800 courses, there are about 30 courses that are meant for skills-conversion for PMETs.  We intend to increase this number to 50 by the end of the year.  There are another 220 courses that are suitable for PMETs to upgrade their skills within their existing

Column: 3624

industries.  So, the industry-coverage is very wide, from manufacturing to healthcare to logistics and even construction.  The Member may be interested to know that for the construction industry, we still need professionals and engineers who have special training in Work and Safety so as to become validation and safety engineers on-site. 

 

Column: 3624

SAF OFFICERS ON BONDS

(Application and approval for leaving service)

     2.  Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Defence (a) whether Singapore Armed Forces officers on bonds can apply to leave the service early and under what circumstances will approval be granted; and (b) how many applications have been made and approvals granted over the years.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Mr Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, Sir, all officers who join the SAF and take up sponsorship are aware that they have a moral obligation to serve out the full period of their sponsorship bonds, which goes beyond the legal obligation to pay back liquidated damages if an officer does not fulfil the bond.  The SAF has a range of important leadership or specialist roles available that serve the organisational needs while catering to officers with different interests and aptitudes.

 

      Officers too are expected to do their best to fulfil their obligations to the organisation, unless there are strong and extenuating circumstances such as medical reasons, that prevent the officers from doing so.  An officer who wishes to be released early while under bond can submit a formal application through the proper process.  The application will be assessed on a case-by-case basis and the officer will be counselled and interviewed by his superior officers.   Since 2000, we

Column: 3625

have allowed three officers to be released prematurely from their bonds.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines):  Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he can review the way the SAF contracts army personnel to make sure that before a person signs a bond with the SAF, the contract terms are clearly explained to him in language that he understands and confirmed with his parents, if he is below 21 years old. Would the Minister agree that while the bonded officer has the moral obligation to serve his bond, the SAF as an employer also has a moral obligation to create a work environment that makes him want to stay and be passionate about his job?  Can I ask the Minister if the SAF's human resource policies ensure that?  And, finally, this is related to the case of the late Dr Allan Ooi.  Sir, as you know, the parents are still asking for answers –

 

     Mr Speaker:  What is your question, Ms Ng?

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong:  Can I ask the Minister, given that MINDEF has convened a board of inquiry and made findings that the matters related to Dr Ooi's service were managed appropriately, would he consider making the findings public or, at least, available to the family?

     Mr Teo Chee Hean: Sir, as the Member's question is obviously motivated by this particular case, I will make my response with some reference to this particular case, even though, as MINDEF has said, it would have much preferred to have conducted such exchanges in private with the family, out of consideration for the family.  Sir, the Member's first question is based on the premise that those who sign up for a MINDEF/SAF sponsorship or scholarship do not fully understand what they are signing.  First, if anyone is signing a sponsorship deed

Column: 3626

and needs clarification on its terms and conditions, he can and should seek these clarifications, which MINDEF has and will continue to provide.  The individual signs a deed voluntarily and is not compelled to do so, until he has fully understood the terms of the sponsorship or scholarship.  This is particularly the case when it is an in-service officer who may already be well in his 20s or 30s, and decides to take up a scholarship or a sponsorship to go on a course for further career development.

 

     Second, most of our sponsorships or scholarships require two sureties to also sign the deed.  These sureties are usually one of the parents, a close relative or someone whom they know well enough to be comfortable in signing the deed.  And MINDEF also provides clarification to these sureties.

 

     The Member has also asked earlier what happens if a person wants to break a bond.  As I have said, all officers who take up the sponsorship know that they have a moral obligation to serve out the full period of their bonds beyond their legal obligation to pay the liquidated damages if they do not fulfil the bonds.  In the case of sponsorship, MINDEF has already taken the first step, which is to provide sponsorship for the course, sometimes with salaries for the officer while he is on course.  So, MINDEF has already fulfilled a fairly major part of the obligations towards the officer by sponsoring him for the programme.  These programmes may be six months or as long as six years, in the case of medical scholarships. 

 

     The SAF invests substantial public funds and time to train these officers.  There is an expectation that such officers will fulfil their moral obligations to serve the organisation in return.  The SAF is not an unreasonable organisation.  The terms and conditions are quite fair and reasonable and that is why we do have people who are prepared to come forward

Column: 3627

to serve the SAF.  There are many interesting and challenging jobs in the SAF.  In fact, in most cases, because the officers whom we choose to sponsor are our better officers, they do have a pick of the better positions available.  So, Sir, on balance, MINDEF does discharge its responsibilities to the officers who choose to take up sponsorship but it is also necessary for the officers to do their best to fulfil their moral obligation to serve the SAF and to serve the country.

Column: 3627

RENTALS AT JTC AND HDB PREMISES

     3.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for National Development in view of the current economic climate, whether his Ministry will put a freeze on all rentals for JTC and HDB premises.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Minister for National Development): The commercial and industrial premises under HDB are generally let on three-year term tenancies during which the rents are fixed.  During tenancy renewals, the rents are adjusted to the prevailing market rent.  Tenants have the option of renewing their tenancies for only one or two years if they expect rents to fall over time.

 

     A freeze on rent increases, as the Member suggested, is not equitable as it will result in different rental subsidies for different tenants who may have renewed their tenancies over different periods of time.  It is also not advisable for HDB rents to be disconnected from market realities.  A better approach to help businesses during the economic downturn is to provide rental rebates.  Such rebates help to lower business costs while allowing for rent adjustments to market conditions.


     Hence, as part of the Government's "Resilience Package" announced earlier this year, HDB will be granting a 15% rebate for all commercial and industrial

Column: 3628

tenants, as well as industrial-land lessees for a year, from January to December 2009.  This 15% rebate includes the savings from property tax rebates which HDB will pass on to tenants. 

 

     HDB also conducts regular reviews of market rents.  In recognition of the prevailing market conditions, HDB has reduced the market rents by 5% since January 2009.  So, instead of freezing, HDB has actually reduced its rentals by 5% in January 2009.  For the small number of tenants who face substantial rental increases in spite of these measures, HDB will stagger the rent increases over the tenancy term.

 

     HDB will monitor the market situation closely to see if additional measures are necessary.  I understand that JTC adopts a similar approach in providing assistance to its industrial tenants.

     Er Lee Bee Wah: Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State, for those tenants who got their rentals adjusted upwards just before the Government announced the 15% rental rebate, would these tenants get their rentals adjusted back to the old rates?

     Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien:  Mr Speaker, as I have said earlier, the rentals are fixed at different times and they are renewed at different periods of time.  So, in order to ensure equity between two tenants, we have to adjust their rental rates to a market rate, such that two tenants who are side by side and have their tenancies renewed at different points in time, will pay the same rent. 

 

     Take, for example, if one tenant has renewed his rental rate three years ago – 2007 – his rental may be 7% to 10% below his neighbour's, who had his rental rate renewed a year or two years later.  If we do not review the rental rate to adjust it to market rate, there will be inequity between two tenants.  So, it is only fair

Column: 3629

for HDB to review the tenants' market rentals and at the same time, provide an across-the-board 15% rebate.  So tenants who may have renewed their leases at different points in time, will be charged the same rentals.  That is a fairer system.  To answer the Member's question, specifically, a tenant who is renewing his tenancy now, will probably mean his tenancy was fixed three years ago before the run-up in the property prices and rental rates.  If we do not review his rental rate, he would be enjoying a significant cost advantage over his fellow tenants next to him.

     Mr Speaker: Mdm Cynthia Phua, last question.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Sir, I would like to declare my interest.  I am working in a retail chain and I am actively negotiating rental as well.  For HDB and other Government agencies, I understand they currently do take into account the rental rebate of 15%


but they do not adjust to match market rental, in view of the rebates. They say, "Because of the rental rebates; hence, I will keep the rental as it is." I think this is the practice. After listening to the Senior Minister of State, I would like to appeal to her to look into adjusting the rental in line with the current market condition, instead of just taking into account an across-the-board 15% rebate.

     Mr Speaker: What is the question?

     Mdm Cynthia Phua: This is the question. I ask the Senior Minister of State to consider adjusting the rental according to the market rate instead of just giving the 15% rebate.

     Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien: Mr Speaker, if you will allow me just to clarify again.  HDB has, in fact, reduced its market

Column: 3630

rental rate by 5% in January 2009. We do take into consideration market conditions.

Column: 3630

PROPERTY DEVELOPERS

(Extension of loan periods)

     4.  Er Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether his Ministry is aware that banks are not willing to extend existing loan periods for property developers to tide them over the current difficult economic times; and (b) whether his Ministry will consider assisting the property developers through any guarantee schemes to help them extend their loan periods.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan):  Sir, under the current economic climate, banks have generally become more cautious in approving loans to businesses and companies, including property developers.  These are commercial decisions that the banks themselves have to take, based on their assessment of the risks as well as the relationships they maintain with their customers.

 

Column: 3631

     Nonetheless, banks are still extending loans to companies that they have assessed to be commercially viable and credit-worthy. Data from the MAS show that total loans to the building and construction sector, of which loans to developers account for the majority, saw a 22% growth in the 12 months leading up to February 2009. While this growth has tapered off in recent months, the total loans to the sector are still at a high level of $50 billion.  

 

     Hence, we do not think the current situation warrants the Government stepping in as guarantor for loans to developers. Banks are still lending to developers, and they are better placed to assess the risks than the Government. Besides bank loans, a number of developers have also managed to raise capital through other means such as rights issue or private placement. 

 

     Nevertheless, the Government is aware that developers, like other businesses, may be facing financial difficulties during this economic downturn. As part of Budget 2009, we have introduced several measures to ease the cashflow of developers. These include the deferment of property tax for land approved for development for up to two years, and the 40% property tax rebates for commercial and industrial properties.

    

     We will continue to monitor the credit situation closely.  If necessary, we are prepared to introduce further measures to help developers through the current downturn.

     Er Lee Bee Wah:  Sir, Budget 2009 has allowed for a one-year extension to the project completion period. But feedback from a lot of  the developers is that the banks will not extend loans for the one-year period at the same rate. In fact, they will be given less favourable terms. So, I would like to ask, is this in line with the original Government's intention?  Second question – how much of the $5.8 billion of the Special Risk-Sharing Initiative (SRI) will flow into the market and, in particular, how much will flow into the real estate market?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan:  The extension of the Project Completion Period (PCP) is to allow developers to stagger or to phase in the development according to the market situation or how they assess the market situation to be.


     The decision of the banks on whether to extend their loans and if so, under what terms, is a separate matter. That is to be decided by the banks based on their relationship with their customers and also based on the assessment of the risks involved. As far as the extension of the PCP is concerned, this has helped many developers and allowed them to phase their developments according to demand.

Column: 3632

However, what is their relationship with the banks, how they negotiate with the banks and what the banks' decision ultimately is, is for the banks to decide. The situation, as I alluded to in my reply, is that the banks are still lending, although they may not lend at the same rates or under the same terms as before. However, that is a situation that I think we have to leave to the banks. 

 

     As to her second question about the SRI – how much of it has flowed down to the construction and the property sector, I do not have the details with me off-hand.  If the Member wishes to file a question, we will be happy to provide those answers. But let me just say that there are other financing initiatives that were announced, that developers as well as construction industry players can avail themselves to. For example, the Member may know that SPRING has an initiative which provides short-term financing or working capital for these Singapore companies. I believe some construction companies and some property companies, which can avail themselves to these funds, have already done so.

 

Column: 3632

SCREEN DOORS AT MRT PLATFORMS

      5.  Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Transport in the light of two passenger fatalities at MRT stations this year (a) whether he will give an update on the status of the programme to install Half Height Platform Screen Doors at MRT platforms that do not have screen doors; (b) whether the Government will accelerate the installation programme to prevent more accidents; and (c) what interim measures can be taken to safeguard passenger safety.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr Teo Ser Luck) (for the Minister for Transport): Sir, I share Dr Lim’s concern about the safety of our train commuters. As announced by the Minister of Transport early last year,

Column: 3633

the Land Transport Authority (LTA) is installing Half-Height Platform Screen Doors (HHPSD) at all elevated MRT stations Lines to further enhance commuter safety. 

 

     Work to install platform screen doors at the first group of MRT stations – Jurong East, Pasir Ris and Yishun – has already started. These three stations will have their platform screen doors functioning by the end of this year. Work on the rest of the 33 elevated stations on the North-South and East-West Lines will be carried out progressively after that. All elevated stations will have platform screen doors by 2012.

 

     Installing platform screen doors on an existing operational MRT line is not a simple task. Workers have to access the tracks each night to cut away the edge of the station platform next to the train track, remove the electrical insulation membrane, drill into the platform to mount the foundation for the platform screen door, install the door frames, put up the actual screen door, and carry out rigorous testing to ensure reliability and safety.


     LTA will try to accelerate this timeline as much as possible. However, a key constraint is that work can only be done for only two-and-a-half hours every night and it is between 1.30 am and 4.00 am. This is because all the elevated stations are operational stations, and we cannot start cutting up the station platform while commuters are still using the station during the day. In addition, the work is carried out at the edge of the platform, which means that workers often have to work from the train tracks.  For their safety, the work can only proceed when the electricity on that section of track has been completely cut off. This is only possible outside the MRT’s normal operating hours after all the passenger trains have been brought back to the

Column: 3634

depots and the track maintenance vehicles have been deployed from the depots every night. It is therefore not possible to extend the working hours without compromising safety or affecting the normal operations of the MRT. Nonetheless, LTA will do what it can without affecting safety to try to complete the programme as soon as possible.


     In the meantime, the Public Transport Operators (PTOs) will continue to proactively ensure safety through the regular broadcasting of recorded voice and video messages on station platforms, to remind commuters not to stand beyond the yellow line or rush to catch a departing train. The operators’ staff will also patrol the station platforms to help commuters who may feel faint or unwell, and advise them to keep away from the platform edge while waiting for the train. In addition, train operators will continue to keep a lookout for dangerous situations as their trains approach the station, and sound the horn or apply the emergency brakes if necessary.


     I would like to urge commuters to take care of their own personal safety. Commuters should observe safety instructions, stand behind the yellow line, and seek assistance from the MRT station officers if they feel unwell. Ultimately, this is a shared responsibility for safety and is best ensured when everyone and every stakeholder does his part.

 

     Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Sembawang): Sir, to wait for end of the year for three stations to be completed and the rest until 2012 seems to be too long. As it is now, there have been two fatalities already, and I am not sure how many are needed before we can speed up the project. I do hope that despite all the technical difficulties that the Senior Parliamentary Secretary has just described, there should be other ways to make it safer.

Objectives of review

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, the current Preservation of Monuments Act (PMA), whose core provisions have largely remained the same since it was enacted in 1971, is no longer adequate for the purpose of monuments protection.  Our enforcement mechanisms need to be more robust to protect these monuments against wilful destruction and illegal renovation works.  In amending the Act, MICA is taking a two-pronged approach – to enhance the enforcement powers of the authority and to revise the penalty framework.

Changes to the enforcement and penalty frameworks

 

     Sir, the new Act will provide for greater control over the repairs, renovation or construction works carried out on national monuments by their owners, principals or agents.  This will be through requiring monument owners to provide information on works done to the monuments and giving the Board the authority to enter a monument to inspect and assess works being carried out, and to take actions to halt the works including requiring the owner to restore the monument.  With more authority, the Board can better monitor and prevent indiscriminate alteration or destruction of monuments, which, once done, may be irreversible.

 

     This enhancement of the Board's enforcement powers will be incomplete if the legislation does not provide for owners and occupiers to have a duty to maintain their monuments.  This is currently absent in the PMA.  A new clause will be introduced, vesting the owners and occupiers with a general duty to ensure that the national monument is properly maintained.  With this clause, the Board will be given the legal authority to issue preservation notices to owners to carry out the restoration work deemed necessary by the Board.

 

     Sir, the second prong is to update the penalty framework which has become outdated in today's context.  The penalty framework of the PMA has been unchanged since the Act was first passed 38 years ago in 1971.  It carries a maximum fine of $5,000 for penalties.  Let me illustrate the inadequacy of this fine quantum with a case in which an owner of a national monument got away with a mere $500 fine for undertaking illegal works some years ago.

This is not the mental image that we want Singapore to be associated with.

 

Column: 3739

     Yet, the right of assembly is often seen as a universal human right. The ability of the people to collectively rise up for a cause is one reason why we are able to bring about change to our society. And for this reason, the right is enshrined in our Constitution which guarantees the right to peaceably assemble and without arms.

 

     To be sure, the right of assembly is not an absolute right. It is often necessary to allow Parliament the right to restrict assemblies and public demonstrations in the interest of public safety and order. Just how much of that right should be curtailed is often a delicate act of balance based on the prevailing norms of the society and the political agenda of the day.

 

     This Bill is therefore welcomed as it seeks to avoid the excesses of public demonstrations seen in recent times and yet recognises the rights of the people to gather to reflect their collective views. While I do not disagree with what the Bill tries to achieve, I do have some issues which I hope the Minister will address.

 

     I support the approach of the Government in trying to provide a clearer and more comprehensive framework to regulate the conduct of outdoor activities. However, in trying to regulate this, one wonders whether the Government may not have gone for the overkill. Currently, under the present proposal, anyone who wishes to organise a public assembly, even if it just meant a one-man assembly, would require a permit from the Commissioner. If the concern relates to security, one wonders whether we have gone to the extreme by taking such a course of action. Surely, there are other security related instruments under our legislative armory that could have dealt with such issues than to go to such extent. Perhaps, we should just keep to the number threshold beyond which a

Column: 3740

permit from the Commissioner for public assembly is required.

 

     Next, the Bill allows for an appeal to be made to the Minister when the Commissioner refuses to grant a permit. I submit, Sir, that such a provision may be less than ideal. Many will criticise this as placing the Government in the position of being the litigant, judge and jury at the same time. Justice must not only be done, but must be seen to be done. With globalisation, the world will also be watching us. There must be some comfort given, not just to us, but to the outside world that the process of review is seen to be fair and impartial. Nothing short of provision for judicial review for the decision of the Commissioner, I believe, will meet the standards that one can expect to have, particularly when the issues behind the organising of the public assembly may be highly politically charged. There must be some assurance that the authorities have acted reasonably and that the process of decision making and appeal is not biased or seen to be biased in any way.

 

     In the current Bill, the right and discretion to grant a permit for public assembly and procession is at the discretion of the Commissioner, who may take into account concerns of public security and law and order issues when deciding. Sir, such drafting does not give anyone who intends to organise outdoor rallies the comfort of knowing for certain whether his application will indeed be granted. Rather than leave the decision entirely to the discretion of the Commissioner, a better approach could perhaps be to ensure that the application for permits to hold public assemblies or public processions be granted as a matter of right unless and until the Commissioner is satisfied that issues of national security or law and enforcement will be an issue. By taking this approach, there is greater certainty on the outcome of the application and this will prevent the

Column: 3741

process from being hijacked by the government of the day to serve a different agenda. Setting a default mode to having permits granted automatically would also resonate well with the provision in our Constitution that guarantees the right and freedom of assembly.

 

     Perhaps what is more surprising about the Bill is the provision in clause 38 that allows a law enforcement officer the right to stop anyone from making any video or taking any pictures that inter alia may have an effect on law enforcement procedures. The provision also allows the police officer the right to confiscate and destroy such videos and pictures. In the run up to the debate on the Bill, the general view in respect of the policy behind this clause relates to the need to maintain the integrity of security operations in critical situation. The recent terrorist attack in Mumbai was cited as an example of how the media, when providing live coverage of the incident, had inadvertently compromised security operations that were taking place at that time.

 

     With all due respect, Sir, I cannot see how one can draw similarities between a terrorist attack and a public assembly that, even at its worst, has gone riotous. As a layman, one would see one operation more as a planned response where secrecy is important and, in the other case, the response is seen more as a spontaneous reaction. In fact, more often than not, when a peaceful assembly turns violent even the most composed of law enforcement officers may be provoked. Police brutality often out of sheer anger, which is not an unnatural human response, cannot be a justification for taking away videos and photos on the basis that such videos and photos may affect ongoing law enforcement actions. The basis on which the Police may act under the present clause is unfortunately

Column: 3742

rather vague. Unless there is greater clarity, there will always be this concern that photos or video footages showing police heavy-handedness or, at worse, brutality, may be taken away for less than noble reasons. I would suggest that the powers to take away such media be given to a third party who can be the independent assessor of whether such records will, in fact, on the balance of probability affect police security law enforcement or security operations. Issues of speed and the need to act fast on the ground can perhaps be dealt with in other ways.

 

     Additionally, the new Bill brings with it the right of police officers to tell the organisers of the public assembly or procession to move on, where among others, the gathering is affecting the business of the place, or disturbing the peaceable conduct of the event, or where it is interfering with the entry or exit of the place. These are rather unusual powers. I understand that the intent here is to avert any trouble or reduce the tension that may arise from participants making a nuisance of themselves in any place. Unfortunately, the proposed Bill in this instance is not clear as to how the powers of the police officers may be exercised. For instance, if the participants were asked to move on, how far they should be asked to go?  Or would the police officer consider whether, on balance, asking the participants to go too far away may result in the assembly or the procession losing its impact on the ground? It is one thing to be placed at the centre stage for the performance and another to be placed at the exit end of the stage. How far should the nuisance go before the police officers will entertain a request from the people affected? Should there be a significant disturbance before the police may be called upon to intervene? The truth of the matter is that no outdoor public assembly or procession of any significant scale is going to result in no disruption to the local or business

Column: 3743

community. Should the Government clarify as to the circumstances under which it will act?

 

     Finally, the Bill places the burden of preventing any illegal assembly or procession from taking place in any premises on the owner or the occupier. In the event that an illegal assembly or procession does take place, the owner or the occupier shall be guilty of an offence and shall on conviction be liable to a fine of not more than $5,000, unless he can demonstrate he has taken all reasonable measures and exercised all reasonable due diligence. Sir, this provision is indeed rather onerous on the owner/occupier of properties. First, it presupposes that the owner/occupier has advanced knowledge of any illegal assembly or procession taking place at the premises; or if it did take place at the premises, the owner/occupier would have the necessary resources to deal with such a contingency. Secondly, this may potentially be a law enforcement matter. To ask the owner/occupier to take measures on a matter that may be of public interest may be unduly onerous or unfair to the owner/occupier if the owner/occupier has to bear the cost of such measures alone. It would be equitable if the Government agrees to bear a part, if not a substantial part, of the cost in this regard.

 

     Sir, although the right to peaceful assembly in public may be curtailed by Acts of Parliament, any act to curtail it should be carried out on the principle that it should be carried out as modestly as possible and only to the extent of absolute necessity. We must be mindful and careful not to pass laws that will eventually make a mockery of our right to peaceful assembly without arms.

 

     With that, Sir, I support the Bill.

 

 

     Mr Shanmugam: Sir, I thank the Members who joined in the debate.  Let me, first, start with the point that has

Column: 3744

been made by a number of Members on assemblies and processions.  Ms Irene Ng, Er Lee Bee Wah, Prof. Thio Li-ann and Mr Sin Boon Ann all have spoken about activities by a single person and whether they should be regulated.  They focus on that and suggest that perhaps we have been too strict.  I will make a number of points and response.

 

     First, it is important to note that the Public Order Act applies only to cause-based activities. A large number of public activities which are not held to promote a cause will not be covered by the Act.  Thus, the scope of when a permit is required under the POA has to be borne in mind.  Second, the Act does not prescribe cause-based activities per se.  Whether the activities are carried out by one or more persons, it only requires the getting of permits.  When an application is received, the police are required to decide whether the activities could affect public security.  It also allows the police to grant a permit with conditions to ensure that risks are minimised.

 

     Third, I would emphasise this.  This aspect of the POA is not quite new law.  That seems to have been lost on a number of Members who have used terms like "stark departure" or that this is a completely new development. The current situation, as I took pains to explain in my Second Reading speech, is not very different from the POA, in terms both of the types of activities covered and the number of persons covered.  First, the MOA applies, that is the Miscellaneous Offences Act, to assemblies and processions of five or more persons.  But that Act has to be read together with the PEMA, and the PEMA applies to any activity which comes under the definition of "Public Entertainment" regardless of the number of persons involved.  Thus, cause-based activities by one or more persons could be public entertainment and would be covered by PEMA, and the term "Public Entertainment" includes any

Column: 3745

lecture, talk, address, debate or discussion.  Thus, it is not as if the POA seeks to cover substantially more area than what the Miscellaneous Offences Act and the PEMA currently already cover.  So it is not a stark departure.  It is a rationalisation that is being carried out together with a substantial relaxation of the current position, as I explained, and I will come back to that again. So what we are seeking to do is rationalise and simplify the approach where we currently have the Miscellaneous Offences Act and the PEMA overlapping each other.

 

     In relation to Er Lee Bee Wah's point that the Public Order Act will duplicate the MOA rules on assemblies and processions, again, as I have stated in my main speech, when this Bill is enacted into law, we will repeal the MOA rules and also a part of the PEMA which regulates public lectures, talks, addresses, debates or discussions.  The intention is that the POA will rationalise and regulate the entire ambit of public cause-based activities.

 

     Fourth, the number of persons, which is five in the Miscellaneous Offences Act, has been used as a proxy for a possible disruptive effect of the activity. But it is more logical to simply focus on the activity rather than choosing an arbitrary number, for example, a group of four intend in causing disruption could pose a far greater threat than a group of 20 who wish to promote a peaceful cause.  Thus, we have decided to focus on the activities and their effects, rather than the number.

 

     I will give two illustrations.  During the Hindraf incident in Malaysia, a local activist protested alone outside the Malaysian Embassy for five days.  Large groups gathered, including many Malaysians who came over.  Understandably, such actions would cause concern for the Embassy officials.  In such

Column: 3746

situations, it is better that the Police have the power to tell the person to stop protesting and move on, if they believed that his actions could be disruptive to public order or public interest.  Second illustration.  During the ASEAN Summit in Singapore in 2007, groups of four persons gathered to evade the permit requirements.

 

     Having a threshold creates an artificial numerical criterion which can lead to a cat-and-mouse game with the Police.  This distracts the Police from their responsibility to secure the safety and security of the event.  We debate in this House with the often implicit assumption that people behave reasonably.  But the unfortunate truth is that there is always a small minority which get up to endless farcical antics outside there and the law has to deal with that.  If one is too low a number, what number should be chosen?  Five?  Four?  Three?  Different countries have different regulatory regimes for outdoor activities.  There are countries which have regimes similar to ours and with a threshold of three persons but it is better for us simply to focus on the effect of the activities.

 

     Fifth, the criteria on which the Police will have to decide is set out in the Act, as opposed to the current situation where the criteria is not clearly spelt out.  The Police will have to consider the possible effect of the activity. 

 

     Sixth, as I have earlier stated, the net effect of the Bill, if enacted into law, together with the proposed exemptions will, in fact, be a substantial relaxation from the current situation.  About 50% of the current permits will no longer be needed.

 

     Seventh, as I have stated in my main speech, cause-based activities can be carried out at the Speakers' Corner.  Members have again debated this issue in this House without really focusing on this

Column: 3747

point about the Speakers' Corner or asking themselves why is that not adequate.  Much of the debate has proceeded on the implicit assumption that there is in fact no place for demonstration.  The point is not for us to prevent such activities but simply to prevent them from being disruptive to the public by requiring applications for permits if you want to have them outside of the places which are designated for them.  With modern methods of filming and circulating online, any cause-based activity can be publicised, whether it is held indoors, for which no permit is needed or if it is held in the Speakers' Corner.  The real question which unfortunately has not been focused on is, should people have the right to organise cause-based activity wherever they like without regard to the impact on the public or should they be required to get a permit?  The Constitution does recognise and protect political freedoms, including the freedom and the right to assemble, but it also provides for appropriate safeguards and restrictions.  That is why I gave some emphasis in my original speech to point out that what we are seeking is a balance.  We provide places where these activities can take place without permits and elsewhere, we require a permit, and that is broadly in line with the current situation and, at the same time, we rationalise the current situation.  The reality is that if people have a genuine cause, the Speakers' Corner can be an effective platform.  Thus, the people affected by the Minibonds used the Speakers' Corner effectively and their views were heard.  That was the very purpose for the setting up of the Speakers' Corner in the first place.

 

     Ms Irene Ng asked if this legislation represents a tightening up.  The answer is that it rationalises the Miscellaneous Offences Act and the PEMA, and read together with the exceptions that will be in the subsidiary legislation, it represents

Column: 3748

a very substantial relaxation from the current position.

 

     Ms Ellen Lee and Prof. Thio Li-ann asked how the police will avoid mistaking a curious bystander as a protester.  In the end, it is really a question of fact.  And if there are any disputes, these are matters for the courts to decide.

 

     Ms Ng also made the point that we are perceived as having tough laws and that the POA may add to that perception.  A section of the international press may certainly take that view.  They are usually ready to prescribe what Singaporeans need.  But what is important for us is that our laws must be just and effective and supported by the people with a stake in our country.  Hence, more important than what some in the international media may think, is what our own people think and also the opinions of investors who come here.  They make the assessments which are relevant to us since they actually have a stake in this country.

 

     Dr Teo, Mr de Souza and Mr Baey referred to recent events in Thailand.  Some months ago, a Thai newspaper expressed the view that Singapore can learn some useful lessons in democracy from Thailand.  Yes – it was said in all seriousness.  But even those who hold that view will, if they are reasonable, accept that Singapore, given its much smaller size and greater limitations, will suffer far more if it has to face a situation and disruptions that Thailand has recently faced.

 

     Members focused on what powers can be exercised by a public officer and whether too much discretion has been given to our police officers and the Minister.  These questions, if they are to be dealt with head-on, really raise basic questions on the appropriate model of government.  Our approach, and we have made it clear, is that the size, the nature of our state and society is such that we need to move quickly and effectively.  We

Column: 3749

are really a small skiff in an ocean.  Thus, the Executive needs to be given power and discretion, and the voters will judge at the end how that power has been exercised.  It does not mean a rule by man as opposed to rule in accordance with the law.  But it means striking the balance in such a way that quick, effective, efficient action is possible to take our country forward.

 

     The opposite philosophical approach is that the Government is subject to a series of stringent checks and balances.  That really underlines much of Prof. Thio's arguments.  And the Executive's ability to act is then weak and fundamentally that approach is one that is suspicious of Executive's authority.  Would that approach work for us?  No.  We are not a large ship that can be unaffected in storms.  Our approach of giving the Executive substantial power has worked for us quite stunningly and not giving the power and subjecting the Executive to the kind of checks and balances would be a far worse alternative.  It does not mean that the power would be exercised unlawfully.  The manner in which the power has to be exercised has to be set out in the law and ultimately the people will have to judge whether the Government has acted properly.  This is the fundamental point and the laws that are introduced, including the Public Order Act, are in keeping with that philosophy.  Thus, yes, the Bill confers substantial discussion on the police but it also sets out how that discretion should be exercised.

 

      In respect of the PEMA regime, Ms Irene Ng said, and I quote, "we have to be consistent in how we deal with mass protests in international conferences, such as APEC."  We need to allow the different groups the space to protest but at the same time ensure that things do not go out of hand and become violent.  It is

Column: 3750

particularly appropriate to consider that in the context of the events of the weekend.  To do away with the need for permits, as some Members have suggested or philosophically are in favour of, assumes that all citizens will be law-abiding and not cause disruptions.  Such an argument would be based on ideal but is it realistic?  You do not really need Pattaya to remind you that such an ideal, though desirable, is quite unrealistic.  The experience of major cities where international events are held give no comfort on this point.  And how do we ensure that protests will always be peaceful?  Can the Police always "ensure that things do not get out of hand and become violent"?  For some APEC meetings, some governments have shut down the whole city.  We cannot and do not want to do this.  Others regulated the space for protest, for example, Sydney, and even then there was bloodshed and violence.  At the WTO meeting in Hong Kong, the protests and demonstrations started out peacefully until the situation went out of control and violence ensued.  Every country has to adopt its own measures in dealing with protests and demonstrations.  There is no consistent way of dealing with these problems among countries.  No two countries' political and social contexts are similar.  But what we are sure is that we do not want violence or bloodshed.  We will allow protests to take place in designated places.  But the protesters cannot demand the right to disrupt the meetings or hold the protests wherever and whenever they like. 

 

     It is also worth reiterating that Singapore is a trophy target for terrorists and the terrorist threat is quite real.  We cannot afford to overlook this aspect of our security landscape.  When major conferences are held in Singapore, we cannot let our guard down and be distracted by protests and demonstrations.  Ultimately, we have to do what we believe is right for Singapore and leave it to Singaporeans to judge our actions

Column: 3751

without worrying too much about the transient views of the international media. 

 

     Dr Teo suggested that we distinguish political activities from recreational and social activities.  That is exactly what the POA seeks to achieve.  As mentioned earlier, we will exempt more recreational and social activities held by the responsible organisers.  Even as we manage in a more targeted manner, the potential risks to public order which outdoor political activities bare.

 

     Mr Baey Yam Keng and Prof. Thio have commented that it is not always easy to distinguish between cause-related and non cause-related events.  The existing criteria have been in place some time in the MOA.  We have not encountered major problems so far and we are not introducing a new definition.  In this context, let me take a specific point that Prof. Thio made.  She asked what about a birthday celebration in a public place?  I think it is ironic that she used the birthday celebration as an example.  Let me point this out.  First of all, the three limbs of the POA replicate the three limbs of the Miscellaneous Offences Act.  So we are not introducing anything new.  Second, I think Prof. Thio will accept

 

 

that there is a difference between a birthday celebration of a prophet in 1964 and a birthday celebration of Prof. Thio – that might be held in a public place.  We can be theoretical about this but the MOA definition has stood the test of time and that is what we are relying upon.  Our intention is to exempt activities which are predominantly social, recreational and commercial in nature.  The details of the exempted activities that statutory boards and charities with IPC status are allowed to organise will be made clear through subsidiary legislation.  Organisers can always make enquiries with the Police and check if a permit is required. 

 

     Let me address some other questions asked by Prof. Thio.  First, she asked

Column: 3752

whether we will create more unrestricted areas and, if so, whether they will be in ulu locations.  She cannot say that the Speakers' Corner is ulu – but it is in a central, visible and accessible location and it has been used effectively.  And indoor activities, as I have pointed out, can be held anywhere.

     In addition, clause 6(4) gives the Commissioner discretion to accept a shorter period of notice.  Prof. Thio has also raised issues about the grounds for refusing to grant permits under clause 7 of the Bill.  Permit applications must be assessed, in context, based on the facts of each case in accordance with the provisions of the Bill.  Applicants who are aggrieved can appeal to the Minister.  The Act does not preclude judicial review. 

 

     Mr Baey asked whether there is a choice for the organiser to decide whether the event should be gazetted as a special event.  A special event does not have to be organised by the Government, such as 

Column: 3753

Formula One Grand Prix.  So long as the event meets the criteria stipulated under clause 21 of the Bill, it can be declared to be so.  In deciding whether to so declare, we will take into account the organiser's views, along with other public order and security considerations.  Mr Baey also asked about the role of auxiliary police under the POA.  Auxiliary police force may be called upon only to supplement resource needs for special event security.  Other policing functions under the Act will be conducted by the Police. 

 

     Dr Teo asked why the Police will issue a Move-On Order if the person is about to commit, is committing, or has just committed an offence.  Move-on followers are intended to be pre-empted to de-escalate a situation before an offence occurs and this can be seen most clearly in the context of regulating outdoor political activities.  Not every offence requires immediate police enforcement action.  However, if the officer assesses that the illegal protest can escalate and post grave public order threats, he can issue a move-on order on the person.  Such an option gives the person engaging in an illegal protest a chance to cooperate with the Police and leave.  This recognises the right to expression without compromising on the police management of public order. 

 

     Mr de Souza has said that move-on directions should be used sparingly, and not for non-urgent cases, such as disputes between neighbours.  We agree.  The intention behind the powers is not, as I have stated, to deal with social disamenities.  They are intended to deal with or prevent public order situations from developing mainly in the context of large-scale events and activities which may escalate into public order situations.  It is not possible to scope out all the circumstances where move-on orders will be used, but I can assure the Member that

Column: 3754

the use of Move-On Orders will be governed by police protocols and they will not be issued wilfully or simply on the request of a member of the public.  There must be a sufficient public order basis to justify the issue and solve an order.

officer's identity is, by itself, necessary to be protected primarily because he is an intelligence or a covet police officer, and the very release of the identity could either prejudice the operations or his safety.  Those are the two fixed situations that we are seeking to cover.  I have heard Members' concerns about whether the definitions are too broad.  We have not gone as far as the English have gone, but we will relook at it.  But it is not our intention to cover, generally, all filming.

with measures like curfews in order to preserve public order.  The proposed Public Order Act is intended for use in normal situations and provides power, but for more general character.

those types of situations.  Election rallies are under the Elections Act and covered by other regulations.

     Now, let us go back to basics.  Does the Workers' Party and Ms Sylvia Lim believe that anyone who feels aggrieved about any matter – whether it is a bad product sold in a shop or any other matter, because then we cannot draw a clear distinction – should be able to take the law into their own hands and congregate and demonstrate as they

Column: 3758
